race.name: UCI GRAVEL SUISSE / THE MAJESTICS
race.tagline: UCI World Series racing in the Swiss Alps - where the world cycling headquarters meets 11,000 feet of alpine suffering

logistics.explanation: International travel to Switzerland required. Geneva airport is closest but still requires train or car rental. Swiss hotels are expensive, and getting bikes through European travel adds complexity. Worth it, but takes planning.

length.explanation: At 104km, the granfondo sits solidly in mid-range territory - substantial but not ultra distance. The 72km mediofondo provides a shorter alternative. Elite rider Tessa Neefjes emphasizes preparation: "I like to arrive early and do proper recons. I study the climbs, the downhills, the gravel and the lines."

technicality.explanation: Described as "pure gravel" that keeps riders "really in nature, with no traffic, proper gravel climbs and technical descents." The course is "constantly up and down" with technical, fast gravel downhills. Less tarmac than some UCI gravel events that "feel more like road races."

elevation.explanation: A monstrous 3,440 meters (11,300 feet) of climbing makes this one of the most vertical races on the UCI calendar. The second half alone packs 2,300m of gain starting at km 50 where "real climbing begins" - pure alpine brutality culminating at Col de la Croix.

climate.explanation: Alpine conditions in July can be deceptively harsh - cool temperatures at altitude, rapidly changing mountain weather, potential for afternoon storms. Finish at Col de la Croix at 1,819m can get cold even in summer.

altitude.explanation: Start at valley level (380m) but climb to 1,819m at Col de la Croix. Moderate altitude impact - noticeable for flatlanders but not the oxygen debt you'd get at 10,000ft+. The highest point comes just 11km before the finish.

adventure.explanation: Starting at the UCI World Cycling Center headquarters then climbing through Vaudois Alps forests and ridges to finish at Col de la Croix. This venue has been awarded the 2029 UCI Gravel World Championships - bucket-list territory for any cycling purist.

prestige.explanation: Part of the UCI Gravel World Series with direct qualification to World Championships. The venue has been awarded the 2029 UCI Gravel World Championships, making this as prestigious as gravel racing gets outside of Unbound. Elite field includes Andreas Seewald and Sophie Wright.

race_quality.explanation: Start area relocates to the UCI headquarters in Aigle creating a unique setting. Swiss precision meets UCI standards with feed zones every 25-30km, full mechanical and medical support, proper timing chips, and characteristic Swiss attention to detail.

experience.explanation: Tessa Neefjes captures the atmosphere: "It feels like a festival before and after the race... You finish and there are happy people everywhere. You can sit on the grass, eat, drink, relax. It feels like a celebration." Rolling out from UCI headquarters adds gravitas.

community.explanation: Growing festival atmosphere with cross-community connection. Tessa Neefjes notes: "After the race, you can talk with amateur riders. You've all ridden the same course, so you can really share the experience." Still building identity as newer UCI event (first edition 2024).

field_depth.explanation: UCI World Series status attracts strong European pros - Andreas Seewald, Sophie Wright, and former Unbound winner Carolin Schiff have all competed. Not major series depth, but serious international competition with World Championship qualification on the line.

value.explanation: Entry fees are reasonable by European UCI standards with Swiss Cycling member discounts (20%) and #fastandfemaleSUI discounts (15%) available. Solid included amenities and fair value for a UCI qualifier, though Switzerland is never cheap overall.

expenses.explanation: Switzerland will destroy your wallet. Hotels range $186-304/night, flights from North America run $1,000+, Swiss food and transport are expensive by any standard. Easily a $2,500-3,500 trip for Americans. Europeans have it easier, but still premium pricing.

distances.name: Granfondo (The Summit)
distances.description: Full UCI qualifying distance for all age groups - from UCI headquarters to Col de la Croix

distances.name: Mediofondo
distances.description: Official qualifying distance for men 60+ and women 50+ age groups

race.terrain: 50% paved / 50% unpaved alpine terrain. Starts flat in Rhone Valley, transitions to steep forest climbs and high-altitude gravel roads. Features a brutal 20% gradient section on Route des Chaux before the Col de la Croix finish.

registration.notes: Early registration discounts available. Swiss Cycling members receive 20% discount.

race.weather: Alpine summer conditions - generally pleasant but highly variable. Cool at altitude, potential for afternoon storms. Temperature can drop significantly at the Col de la Croix finish (1,819m).
uniqueCharacteristics: Starts at UCI World Cycling Center headquarters in Aigle - the global home of cycling
Host venue for 2029 UCI Gravel World Championships
Part of UCI Gravel World Series with Worlds qualification
One of the highest elevation-per-km ratios in the UCI series
Multi-discipline weekend: TT Friday, Road Saturday, Gravel Sunday
Finish at Col de la Croix (1,819m) with stunning alpine views
race.popularity: High - premier Swiss gravel event and UCI World Series qualifier

final_verdict.one_liner: The UCI's backyard playground where 3,300 meters of climbing separates tourists from gravel racers.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need legitimate climbing legs and a gravel bike that can handle 20% grades on loose surfaces. The second half destroys weekend warriors—if you can't sustain power on steep off-road climbs above 1,500 meters, the Route des Chaux will expose you. Come for the prestige and alpine scenery, but expect to earn every meter of that Col de la Croix finish.
final_verdict.alternatives: Unbound 200 offers similar suffering with less elevation but more distance and heat. Traka 360 in Spain delivers comparable climbing with better weather windows and fewer altitude issues for sea-level dwellers.

course_description.character: Starting at cycling's global headquarters in Aigle, this course lulls you through 30 miles of Rhone Valley false confidence before unleashing 3,300 meters of vertical punishment. The second half abandons civilization for alpine forest tracks and 20% wooden ladders disguised as bike paths. It's less gravel race, more high-altitude survival exam with a fancy UCI stamp.

suffering_zones.label: Ollon Wake-Up Call
suffering_zones.desc: First off-road climb hits 10% average gradient for 3 miles. Your legs haven't warmed up, but the Alps don't care about your preparation routine.

suffering_zones.label: Valley Floor Intermission
suffering_zones.desc: Flat roads through the Rhone Valley where you'll foolishly think this race is manageable. Use this time to eat everything in your pockets—you won't get another chance.

suffering_zones.label: The Real Race Begins
suffering_zones.desc: Everything changes at kilometer 80 when pavement ends and the woods swallow you whole. From here it's 2,300 meters of climbing to the finish with no mercy.

suffering_zones.label: Route des Chaux Punishment
suffering_zones.desc: Twenty percent gradients on loose gravel through dense forest. Your bike becomes a hiking accessory and your quads become strangers.

course_description.signature_challenge: The Route des Chaux section after mile 49 strips away any illusion that this is a normal gravel race. Twenty percent pitches on technical forest tracks at 5,000+ feet elevation turn bikes into anchors and legs into concrete. The thing nobody tells you: it's not just steep, it's steep when you're already cooked from the altitude and previous 2,000 meters of climbing.
